'''Tavari''' were the [[fays]] of the woods, according to the early version of the [[legendarium]] in ''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]''.<ref>{{PE|14}}, "[[The Creatures of the Earth]]", p. 10</ref>

They arrived to the world with [[Aulë]] and [[Yavanna]], along with many other types of fays.<ref>{{LT1|III}}, p. 66</ref>

== Etymology ==
The name ''Tavari'' is in [[Qenya]], being a possible plural<ref group=note>The actual plural of ''tavar'' given in the ''[[Qenya Lexicon]]'' is '''''tavarni'''''.</ref> form of ''tavar'' ("dale-sprite").<ref name=Tav>{{PE|12}}, entry '''TAVA, ?TAFA''', p. 90</ref> The [[Gnomish]] cognate of ''tavar'' was '''''tavor''''' ("a wood fay").<ref>{{PE|11}}, entry '''tavor''', p. 69</ref>

The word ''tavar'' is derived from the root [[TAVA]] ("beam"), with "beam" here referring to the [[Old English]] ''béam'' ("tree, piece of wood, rafter, pillar").<ref name=Tav/>

The name suggests that the wood-fays 'used' the forest as their home, and that such forests were watched or guarded by the fays.<ref>{{PE|16}}, p. 80</ref>
== Other versions of the legendarium ==
In a later version of the legendarium from ''[[The Etymologies]]'' (1930s), there appear the terms '''''tavaro(n)''''' (male)/'''''tavaril''''' (female), meaning "dryad; spirit of the woods".<ref name=Taw>{{LR|P3}}, entry '''TÁWAR'''-, p. 391</ref>

The hypothetical earlier forms of these names were '''''tawaro''''' or '''''tawarë'''''.<ref name=Taw/>

== Inspiration ==
According to [[C.S. Lewis]], [[Tolkien]] once told him that the historical people in a sense did not falsely claim to see "[[nymphs]] in the fountains and woods and dryads in the wood", since the production of food was closely connected to one's own land and territory: people came to internalize the nature surrounding them.<ref>[[C.S. Lewis]], ''[[The Collected Letters of C.S. Lewis: Family Letters 1905-1931]]'', letter from 1930</ref>

It is possible that Tolkien at one point drew inspiration from the concept of the ''Tavari'' while creating the race of [[Ents]], since in one letter, Tolkien explores the possibility that the Ents were "[[spirits|souls]]" that were sent to inhabit (animate) trees, or that became [[trees]] themselves.<ref>{{L|247}}</ref><ref group=note>This is pure speculation.</ref>
